IMAGE-HIGH-RES JECHEM 439 S2095-4956(17)30891-4 10.1016/j.jechem.2017.10.015 Fig. 1 SEM images of (a and b) Co2(OH)2CO3 nanowire arrays, (c and d) Co3O4 nanowire arrays and (e and f) Co9S8@ Co3O4 core/shell nanowire arrays. Fig 1 Fig. 2 TEM-HRTEM images of (a and d) Co2(OH)2CO3 nanowire arrays, (b and e) Co3O4 nanowire arrays, (c and f) Co9S8@Co3O4 core/shell nanowire arrays and (g) EDS elemental mapping images of Co, S and O elements of the Co9S8@Co3O4 samples. Fig 2 Fig. 3 XRD patterns of (a) Co2(OH)2CO3 nanowire arrays, (b) Co3O4 nanowire arrays and Co9S8@Co3O4 core/shell nanowire arrays, XPS characterizations of Co3O4 and Co9S8@Co3O4 core/shell nanowire arrays: (c) XPS survey spectrum; (d) core-level Co 2p XPS spectra; (e) core-level S 2p XPS spectra and (f) core-level O1s XPS spectra. Fig 3 Fig. 4 OER performances: (a) LSV curves at 5 mV s−1; (b) CV curves of different electrodes at a scan rate of 1 mV s−1; (c) Tafel plots. CV curves of different electrodes in double layer region at various scan rates ranging from 4 to 20 mV s−1: (d) Ni foam, (e) Co2(OH)2CO3, (f) Co3O4, (g) Co9S8@Co3O4 electrodes. Fig 4 Fig. 5 CV curves of different electrodes in double layer region at various scan rates ranging from 20 to 100 mV s−1: (a) Ni foam, (b) Co2(OH)2CO3, (c) Co3O4, (d) Co9S8@Co3O4 electrodes. Fig 5 Fig. 6 (a) The ratio of current density with various scan rates and (b) Nyquist plots of the Ni foam, Co2(OH)2CO3, Co3O4 and Co9S8@Co3O4 electrodes (equivalent circuit in inset); (c) Electrochemical stability of the Co9S8@Co3O4 electrodes at different current densities. Fig 6 Assembling Co9S8 nanoflakes on Co3O4 nanowires as advanced core/shell electrocatalysts for oxygen evolution reaction Shengjue Deng a 1 Shenghui Shen a 1 Yu Zhong a Kaili Zhang a Jianbo Wu b Xiuli Wang a Xinhui Xia a * Jiangping Tu a a State Key Laboratory of Silicon Materials, Key Laboratory of Advanced Materials and Applications for Batteries of Zhejiang Province, and School of Materials Science and Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou 310027, Zhejiang, China State Key Laboratory of Silicon Materials Key Laboratory of Advanced Materials and Applications for Batteries of Zhejiang Province, and School of Materials Science and Engineering Zhejiang University Hangzhou Zhejiang 310027 China b Zhejiang Provincial Key Laboratory for Cutting Tools, Taizhou University, Taizhou 318000, Zhejiang, China Zhejiang Provincial Key Laboratory for Cutting Tools Taizhou University Taizhou Zhejiang 318000 China * Corresponding author. 1 Shengjue Deng and Shenghui Shen contributed equally to this work. Rational design of advanced cost-effective electrocatalysts is vital for the development of water electrolysis. Herein, we report a novel binder-free efficient Co9S8@Co3O4 core/shell electrocatalysts for oxygen evolution reaction (OER) via a combined hydrothermal-sulfurization method. The sulfurized net-like Co9S8 nanoflakes are strongly anchored on the Co3O4 nanowire core forming self-supported binder-free core/shell electrocatalysts. Positive advantages including larger active surface area of Co9S8 nanoflakes, and reinforced structural stability are achieved in the Co9S8@Co3O4 core/shell arrays. The OER performances of the Co9S8@Co3O4 core/shell arrays are thoroughly tested and enhanced electrocatalytic performance with lower over-potential (260 mV at 20 mA cm−2) and smaller Tafel slopes (56 mV dec−1) as well as long-term durability are demonstrated in alkaline medium. Our proposed core/shell smart design may provide a new way to construct other advanced binder-free electrocatalysts for applications in electrochemical catalysis. Graphical abstract Co9S8 nanoflakes@Co3O4 nanowire core/shell arrays prepared by a facile and powerful sulfurization method and show superior electrocatalytic performance with good durability. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Metal sulfides Nanoflakes Nanowires Core/shell arrays Electrocatalysis Oxygen evolution reaction 1 Introduction Efficient catalyst for oxygen evolution reaction (OER) plays an important role in producing green chemical fuels. But the anodic OER relies largely on the development of advanced green electrocatalysts [1–8]. Currently, iridium/ruthenium oxides (IrO2/RuO2) are considered as the most promising electrocatalysts for OER. However, their high cost, scarcity and compromised stability severely hinder their widespread applications in OER [9–11]. To overcome these headwinds and achieve exceptional catalytic performance, it is urgent to explore high-performance cost-effective electrocatalysts such as metal oxides [12–14], phosphides [15], nitrides [16], selenides and sulfides [17]. Of these candidates, cobalt sulfide (Co9S8) has been the subject of intense research because of its high catalytic activity and superior electrochemical stability for OER [18,19]. Though cobalt sulfide is endowed with these fascinating virtues, the OER performance of the bulk Co9S8 is still unsatisfactory due to poor electronic conductivity and little exposed active sites [20–22]. Therefore, appropriate steps must be taken on Co9S8 to increase the active surface area and strengthen electrocatalytic kinetics involving transfer rates of ions/electrons to acquire high catalytic activity. Up to now, a variety of Co9S8 electrodes have been reported by developing Co9S8 nanostructures or compositing with conductive matrixes. For instance, Co9S8@N/P-doped carbon composite electrocatalysts prepared by Liu et al. [18] exhibited a low overpotential of 400 mV at 10 mA cm−2 by a one-step molten-salt calcination method. Cao et al. [23] reported cobalt sulfide/porous N-doped carbon with a low Tafel slope of 65 mV dec−1 by a high-temperature calcination method. Co9S8/graphene synthesized by Dou et al. [22] displayed improved electrocatalytic performance with an OER overpotential of ∼0.41 V via a hydrothermal method. Despite enhanced electrocatalytic performance, the electrocatalytic performance of powder Co9S8-based catalysts is greatly undermined because the active sites might be covered or annihilated during the preparation of test-electrode with insulating polymer binders. In addition, the prepared condition for the published Co9S8-based electrocatalysts always involves high temperature sulfurization, which would decrease active sites due to aggregation of nanoparticles. Hence, low-temperature sulfurization method is highly desirable for construction of binder-free Co9S8-based electrocatalysts, especially for the self-supported Co9S8-based film electrocatalysts. In this work, for the first time, we directionally construct novel porous Co9S8 nanoflakes@ Co3O4 nanowires core/shell arrays as robust binder-free electrocatalysts for OER in alkaline medium by one-step low-temperature sulfurization method. Arising from larger active surface area of Co9S8 nanoflakes, higher electrical conductivity and reinforced structural stability, the as-prepared Co9S8@Co3O4 core/shell arrays exhibits noticeable electrocatalytic performance with a low overpotential of 260 mV at 20 mA cm−2 and low Tafel slopes of 56 mV dec−1 for OER in alkaline medium. Furthermore, our Co9S8@Co3O4 core/shell electrocatalysts also possess superior long-term durability with no decay after 30 h. Our versatile fabrication method and smart design may trigger new interest for construction of advanced non-noble metal electrocatalysts for oxygen evolution reaction. 2 Experimental The Co9S8@Co3O4 core/shell arrays were prepared by a facile combined hydrothermal-sulfurization method. The detailed process was as follows. First, uniform Co2(OH)2CO3 nanowire arrays were prepared by a one-step hydrothermal method. In a typical synthesis, 3 mmol Co(NO3)2, 6 mmol NH4F and 15 mmol urea were dissolved in 80 mL deionized water to form homogeneous solution. Clean nickel foam was used as the substrate. Then, the above solution was transferred into a Teflon-linked steel autoclave and kept at 120 °C for 8 h to form Co2(OH)2CO3 nanowire arrays. After naturally cooling to room temperature, the Co2(OH)2CO3 nanowire arrays were rinsed by deionized water and annealed at 350 °C in argon for 2 h to form Co3O4 nanowire arrays. Then, the above Co3O4 nanowire arrays were subject to a low-temperature sulfurization process. The Co3O4 nanowire arrays were immersed into solution of 0.1 M Na2S and kept at 90 °C for 9 h to form the final Co9S8@Co3O4 core/shell arrays. Morphologies and microstructures of the as-prepared samples were characterized using a field emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM, Hitachi SU8010) and transmission electron microscope (TEM, JEOL 2100F). The crystal structure was confirmed using X-ray diffraction (XRD) reactor with Cu Kα radiation (RigakuD/Max-2550). The chemical composition and valence state were characterized by the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) with an ESCALAB_250Xi X-ray photoelectron spectrometer. OER performances of all samples were conducted using an electrochemical workstation (CH Instrument 660D) with a standard three-electrode setup at room temperature, in which platinum foil and saturated calomel electrode (SCE) and the as-prepared samples were used as the counter electrode, reference electrode and working electrode, respectively. The electrolyte was 1 M KOH solution. All potentials were referred to the RHE. The conversion of E (RHE) can be achieved based on the following equation: E (RHE ) = E (SCE ) + 1.0674. The CV test was first performed to stabilize the current with the 20 cycles at a scan rate of 100 mV s−1. Then, the linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) tests were conducted at a scan rate of 5 mV s−1. The Tafel plots were derived from LSV curves with a scan rate of 1 mV s−1. The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was carried out at the polarization voltage corresponding to current density of 10 mA cm−2, in a frequency range from 100 kHz to 50 mHz with an AC amplitude of 5 mV. The stability test was conducted at different constant current densities (10, 30, and 50 mA cm−2) for 10 h each. All these results were obtained by IR-compensation. 3 Results and discussion All morphologies of samples are monitored by SEM images. Fig. 1 (a) and (b) shows that the hydrothermal-synthesized Co2(OH)2CO3 nanowires of 70 − 100 nm are uniformly grown onto the nickel foam substrate. These Co2(OH)2CO3 nanowires exhibit a smooth appearance and develop independently forming a three-dimensional porous structure. After annealing, the Co2(OH)2CO3 nanowires convert into Co3O4 nanowires, while the morphology does not change much and maintains the nanowire array architecture (Fig. 1c and d). Apparently, the Co3O4 nanowires of 80 − 110 nm display rough surface and are composed of closely packed secondary nanoparticles of 20 − 40 nm. Moreover, there are lots of nanopores left between these nanoparticles. At the last stage, the Co9S8@Co3O4 core/shell arrays are obtained after a facile low-temperature sulfurization process. Note that the Co3O4 nanowire core is completely decorated with interconnected 3D net-like Co9S8 nanoflakes forming core/shell configuration (Fig. 1e and f). Importantly, the 3D porous structure is still well kept, indicating that the sulfurization process is gentle and will not damage the whole structure. TEM measurements were performed to further reveal the evolution of phase and detailed microstructures. Fig. 2 (a) shows the typical TEM images of the Co2(OH)2CO3 nanowire and proves its smooth texture. The diameter of Co2(OH)2CO3 nanowire is verified to be 70 − 100 nm. Also, the single crystalline characteristics of the Co2(OH)2CO3 nanowire is demonstrated in Fig. 2(d). The measured lattice spacing is ∼0.50 nm, which matches well with the (0 2 0) crystal planes of Co2(OH)2CO3 phase (JCPDS 48-0083) [24]. Compared to the Co2(OH)2CO3 nanowire, the Co3O4 nanowire (Fig. 2c and d) consists of a large amount of interconnected primary nanoparticles of 20 − 40 nm and presents a rough texture with numerous mesoporous structures arising from the continuous release of H2O and CO2 during the thermal treatment of Co2(OH)2CO3 nanowire. HRTEM image of the Co3O4 nanowire exhibits a polycrystalline nature. The measured lattice spacing is about 0.24 nm (Fig. 2d), which are well indexed to (3 1 1) planes of Co3O4 phase (JCPDS 42-1467) [25,26]. As for the Co9S8@Co3O4 sample apparently, the Co3O4 nanowire is completely covered by the thin Co9S8 nanoflakes, forming a homogeneous core/shell structure (Fig. 2e and f). The measured lattice spacing of 0.30 and 0.31 nm is attributed to the (3 1 1) and (2 2 2) plane of Co9S8 phase (JCPDS 65-6801), respectively [27]. According to the inset-HRTEM image (Fig. 2f), the Co9S8 and Co3O4 are well noticed and their combination is very strong. In the meantime, the uniformity of the as-prepared Co9S8@Co3O4 is proven by EDS elemental mapping images (Fig. 2g). Uniform distributions of S, Co, and O elements are detected in the sample, suggesting the successful synthesis of high-quality Co9S8@Co3O4 core/shell arrays. The above results are also supported by the following XRD and XPS analysis. As shown in Fig. 3 (a), the diffraction peaks match well with the crystal structure of Co2(OH)2CO3 (JCPDS 48-0083) in addition to the peaks of nickel foam substrate (Fig. 3a). After heat treatment, the peaks of Co2(OH)2CO3 vanish and new diffraction peaks of (2 2 0), (3 1 1), (5 1 1) and (4 4 0) planes belonging to Co3O4 phase (JCPDS 42-1467) appear. After sulfurization, except for the diffraction peaks of Co3O4, the other peaks are well indexed to Co9S8 phase (JCPDS 65-6801) [20], suggesting the successful preparation of Co9S8@Co3O4 core/shell arrays. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted to further reveal the surface composition. For the Co9S8@Co3O4 core/shell arrays, the XPS survey spectrum indicates the presence of Co, S and O elements (Fig. 3c), consistent with the results of EDS mapping above. Fig. 3(d) shows the high-resolution Co 2p spectra of both samples. Two core levels (Co 2p 3/2 and Co 2p 1/2) match well with those reported for Co3O4 [28]. The weak satellite peaks of Co3O4 indicate its typical spinel structure owing to Co2+ ions occupying tetrahedral lattice sites and Co3+ ions in octahedral sites, respectively [29,30]. As for Co9S8@Co3O4 sample, the emergence of satellite peaks (at 785.6 and about 802.7 eV) is in good agreement with the breakdown of the superficial Co3O4 structure after sulfurization and the presence of Co2+. In addition, the two core levels of Co 2p 3/2 and Co 2p 1/2 display a positive shift compared to Co3O4 sample, which indicates the successful formation of Co9S8 grown on Co3O4 nanowire [28,31,32]. Meanwhile, the above result is also supported by S 2p and O 1s spectra (Fig. 3e and f). Two core levels (S 2p 3/2 and S 2p 1/2) are approximately located at 161.2 and 163.4 eV, respectively, in agreement with the chemical states of Co9S8 [32]. It must be pointed out that the intensity of the peak at 531.3 eV has no noticeable change after sulfurization treatment, corresponding to the surface OH− [2]. However, the peak at 529.8 eV disappears, further confirming the formation of Co9S8. The formation mechanism of Co9S8 on the Co3O4 is probably due to the following reason. The Na2S will hydrolyze in the aqueous solution at 90 °C and form lots of active ions and reactants such as S2−, HS− and H2S, which would react with the surface of Co3O4 nanowires. The dissolved Co2+ and Co3+ are recombined with S2− and self-assembled with each other forming interconnected Co9S8 nanoflakes on the surface of Co3O4 nanowires. The electrochemical performance of Co9S8@Co3O4 core/shell arrays as electrocatalysts for oxygen evolution reaction are thoroughly characterized using a simple three-electrode system in 1 M KOH solution. In our work, four different electrodes (Ni foam substrate, Co2(OH)2CO3 nanowire arrays, Co3O4 nanowire arrays and Co9S8@Co3O4 core/shell arrays) are tested for OER comparison. Fig. 4 (a) shows the linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curves of the as-prepared electrodes. Significantly, the Co9S8@Co3O4 electrode displays the best OER performance with the lowest overpotential (260 mV at the current density of 20 mA cm−2), superior to the Ni foam (400 mV), Co2(OH)2CO3 (360 mV) and Co3O4 (300 mV) electrodes. Note that the overpotential of Co9S8@Co3O4 electrode is also substantially lower than recently reported Co9S8-based catalysts, such as hollow Co9S8 microplates (293 mV) [33], and N/S co-doped porous carbon tube/ Co9S8 (330 mV) [32,34] and Fe3O4@Co9S8/rGO (340 mV) [34]. The above results of LSV curves are supported by the CV plots (Fig. 4b). In the meantime, the Co9S8@Co3O4 electrode shows the lowest Tafel slope of 56 mV dec−1 (Fig. 4c), much lower than the Ni foam (138 mV dec−1), Co2(OH)2CO3 (78 mV dec−1) and Co3O4 (72 mV dec−1) electrodes, indicating its fastest OER process. In order to further understand the improved OER performance, the electrochemical active surface area (ECSA) of the above samples was calculated by performing the double-layer capacitance (DLC) based on the CV results at different scan rates (Figs. 4d–g and 5 ) [35]. The obtained current density is plotted as a function with different scan rates in Fig. 6 (a). The ECSA value is equal to the half of the slope value. Remarkably, the ECSA value of Co9S8@Co3O4 electrode is up to 38 mF cm−2, much larger than the Ni foam (2 mF cm−2), Co2(OH)2CO3 (23 mF cm−2) and Co3O4 (28 mF cm−2) electrodes, suggesting the markedly enhanced active area of the Co9S8@Co3O4 electrode. EIS tests were carried out to further deepen the understanding of the electrochemical behavior during the OER process. Fig. 6(b) shows the Nyquist plots of different electrodes (equivalent circuit in inset). The equivalent circuit consists of the solution resistance R s in series with a parallel connection of the double-layer capacitance (CPE) and the charge transfer impedance (R ct). As shown in Fig. 6(b), the smallest circle diameter of the Co9S8@Co3O4 electrode suggests that the Co9S8@Co3O4 electrode possesses the lowest charge transfer resistance (R ct) of ∼2 Ω corresponding to the fastest electrocatalytic reaction kinetics. These results are owing to smart design of Co9S8@Co3O4 core/shell architecture. Direct growth of Co9S8@Co3O4 core/shell architecture on nickel foam substrates avoids the use of insulated binders. The 3D net-like Co9S8 nanoflakes with large active surface area increase contact area between electrolyte and active materials [36,37]. Our designed core/shell architecture can utilize the synergistic effects between Co9S8 and Co3O4. First, Co3O4 core can provide strong support for the Co9S8 nanoflakes, and keep structure stable during the OER cycles. Second, the porous Co9S8 nanoflakes shell will not block the contact between Co3O4 core and electrolyte. The Co3O4 core can still be accessed by electrolyte and initiate the catalytic reaction. It implies that both Co3O4 core and Co9S8 nanoflakes work together to achieve high OER performance. It is noteworthy that the porous core/shell structure would further increase the electrolyte-material contact area and enhance ion diffusion, which is very critical to high-rate electrocatalysis [38,39]. Cycling stability is also vital to an advanced electrocatalysts for OER. Noticeably, the Co9S8@Co3O4 core/shell architecture also possesses excellent ultra-long OER durability. As presented in Fig. 6(c), the Co3O4@Co9S8 electrode maintains higher activity and more stable life span at different current densities ranging from 20 to 50 mA cm−2 than other counterparts. 4 Conclusions To sum up, we have demonstrated a facile and effective low-temperature sulfurization method to construct interconnected Co9S8 nanoflakes on the Co3O4 nanowire core as robust and advanced core/shell array electrocatalyst for OER. Owing to unique advantages of larger active surface area of Co9S8 nanoflakes, and reinforced structural stability, the as-prepared Co9S8@Co3O4 core/shell architecture arrays exhibit excellent electrocatalytic activity with low overpotentials of 260 mV at 20 mA cm−2 and low Tafel slopes of 56 mV dec−1 as well as stable cyclability for OER in alkaline medium. Our work is proven as a feasible way for construction of advanced metal sulfides electrocatalysts for water splitting. coredata.dc:description: Rational design of advanced cost-effective electrocatalysts is vital for the development of water electrolysis. Herein, we report a novel binder-free efficient Co9S8@Co3O4 core/shell electrocatalysts for oxygen evolution reaction (OER) via a combined hydrothermal-sulfurization method. The sulfurized net-like Co9S8 nanoflakes are strongly anchored on the Co3O4 nanowire core forming self-supported binder-free core/shell electrocatalysts. Positive advantages including larger active surface area of Co9S8 nanoflakes, and reinforced structural stability are achieved in the Co9S8@Co3O4 core/shell arrays. The OER performances of the Co9S8@Co3O4 core/shell arrays are thoroughly tested and enhanced electrocatalytic performance with lower over-potential (260 mV at 20 mA cm−2) and smaller Tafel slopes (56 mV dec−1) as well as long-term durability are demonstrated in alkaline medium. Our proposed core/shell smart design may provide a new way to construct other advanced binder-free electrocatalysts for applications in electrochemical catalysis.

coredata.dc:title: Assembling Co9S8 nanoflakes on Co3O4 nanowires as advanced core/shell electrocatalysts for oxygen evolution reaction
